Fields.DialogueText: Kaga, about the bomber fleet...
Yes, Kanchou, I've had some thoughts on that recently.
Good. I've spoken with a few of the engineers about the mechanics and they have some ideas.
Ah. Excellent, excellent.
And yet you seem less than excited by this news.
Hmm? No, believe me, I'm ecstatic. I was just lost in thought about bombers in the abstract. Distance and indirect fire, specifically.

Fields.MenuText: Fascinating, but ultimately pointless.
Fascinating, but I respectfully fail to see the point.
Fascinating. I'm interested in hearing more.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you find it fascinating, Kanchou. You should.
Fascinating? Thank you... I wonder if there's a formula for showing...
Lip service gets you nowhere, Kanchou. You must commit!
You've hit upon something big, haven't you?
Potentially. I have a feeling it'll put a big dent in these Funayūrei!
I'd expect nothing less from Lady Kaga!
@BATTLE
Careful how you throw that title around, Kanchou. I might get used to it.
Kanchou, any thoughts on the distance question?
Not remotely. I've had more than a few tangible issues on my hands to deal with.
Sarcasm aside, Kanchou, this is rather important.
Don't you think the state of the ship is more important than the state of your thoughts?
Since they are one and the same... no, no I don't.

Fields.MenuText: One and the same? I knew you were connected, but not that deeply!
Don't get that attached to your theories. It's not a matter of life and death.
As in we can never rid the ship of your presence?

Fields.DialogueText: I am the ship. The ship is me. What's so hard about that?
Everything is, Kanchou. That's how you stay alive.
I know of at least one attempt to exorcise a Belle. It went... poorly.
One day I'll figure out your tell. On that day, you won't be able to bluff me ever again.
Don't you know by now, Kanchou? I never bluff... except when I do.
Kaga, would you kindly bring me a rag soaked in cold water?
Of course, but why?
Because I suddenly have a headache.
I can't imagine why.
Never thought I'd see the day you were stumped.
@BATTLE
What can I say? You've got a talent for it.
I'm that inscrutable?
We'll call it that, sure. Maybe a smoking Morgana hulk will help me focus on the solution to your mystery.
... and that's why distance has always been our greatest advantage.
It wasn't distance so much as weather that saved Japan from the Mongols.
Was it weather, or was it something more?
Before you and your kind appeared, I would have said the weather. Looking at you now, though, well... perhaps it was something more.
Perhaps it was. Regardless, it was distance that saved us. Without the distance between the mainland and us, the Mongols wouldn't have lost their nerve and been destroyed in retreat.

Fields.MenuText: If distance is what you say, then distance is the answer.
I hate to say you're wrong, so I won't... but I will disagree politely.
No, you're wrong. I can't accept something so simple as distance.

Fields.DialogueText: It is, and it is. Thank you for finally seeing my point.
Think as you will, Kanchou, but my mind is made up.
I don't care what you think when I'm right, Kanchou, and I'm absolutely right here!
Then why are we arguing?
You're the one arguing, Kanchou. I'm the one explaining.
*ALARM*
Come, let us see if distance can save the poor Funayūrei today. Here's a hint: it's one of my greatest weapons.
@BATTLE
Tell me, Kaga, if distance is good for all things, then how did societies come into being?
Distance between settlements allowed for differences to grow? Differences allowed uniqueness, which in turn allowed for innovation?
Are you asking me or telling me?
Is there a difference?

Fields.MenuText: Why is everything a question with you suddenly?
Is this how you solve all your issues? By making others answer them for you?
How can you be so simple on the one hand and so complex on the other?

Fields.DialogueText: Do you always answer a question with another question, Kanchou?
Is there a better way?
Why does it matter? You can't just deal with it?
Gah! Won't something save me from this interminable questioning?
Will that do?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
It'll have to.
Kanchou...
No more questions!
Ever? Just kidding, just kidding!
Bah. That does bring up an interesting point, however. I can't help but notice you've become more inquisitive since we started talking about the bomber fleet.
Have I? I mean, that's interesting.
Interesting indeed. I have to wonder if perhaps digging deeper into your desires has opened a door to your mind. It might be worth exploring.
Might be worth exploring? Why just 'might'?

Fields.MenuText: Because frankly, I'm afraid of what else might be hiding in there.
Because frankly, it may just be a phase.
Because frankly, I just don't want to get lost in the emptiness.

Fields.DialogueText: I have no skeletons, Kanchou, so save the sarcasm for someone else.
You think my deep desires are a phase? Save the sarcasm, Kanchou.
The vastness contained within me is fathomless and enigmatic, Kanchou. You're probably not equipped to sound it, no matter how sarcastic you are.
Who said it was sarcasm?
I did, because anything else could be seen as insulting. I choose otherwise.
You're worried about insults when there are Morganas on the prowl?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
No, I just figured I'd try speaking your language. You seem the type to get worked up over trivialities like that.
... Is it working?
Bridge. Now.
All right, let's talk about this theory of yours.
Distance equals safety?
That one. I've been thinking that perhaps it is not distance so much as visibility.
Oh, this should be interesting. Explain, if you please.
Distance simply keeps you out of sight. In the case of our bombers and you... er, the ship... by putting ourselves away from our opponent, we achieve safety.
So far you're arguing my point, so I like this.
But wait, here it gets different. If our bombers are close enough to be seen, the enemies can launch fighters to attack them, yes?
Hence my preference for hitting them from beyond the curvature of the earth!
So it stands to reason that if they were close but invisible, they could still be effective. Conversely, if they were far away but spotted, they would be in danger.
So instead of this being 'distance equals safety', it should be...

Fields.MenuText: The captain is always right.
Visibility equals danger.
Safety comes at a price.

Fields.DialogueText: Deflate your head or I'll never see the Morganas coming.
I see your logic, and by that reasoning it's extremely vulnerable.
All things come at a price, Kanchou. This is no exception.
*ALARM*
Well, I certainly feel like we made progress today.
I'll say. I was beginning to think you'd never listen to me.
Don't get me wrong, Kanchou - you've got your moments. Let's hope this one lasts us the battle.
@BATTLE
Why wouldn't I? It's not often I get the chance to completely shoot you down.
Do you view every debate as a contest?
Kaga, would you...
*ALARM*
This close? Kaga to the bridge; all hands to action stations!
@BATTLE
That was an ill-timed attack on their part.
One could say that, yes.
One could? I believe I just did.

Fields.MenuText: My apologies. Please don't hold my thoughtlessness against me.
You did. You're right. I apologize.
Oh, no.  You're not playing games with casual conversation again.

Fields.DialogueText: Apology accepted, Kanchou, but I reserve the right to hold things against you.
Of course I'm right. We could wrap up the war inside a year if more people saw that.
It's not my shift to work on the planes, Kanchou. I've got to entertain myself somehow.
Er... Kanchou, are you feeling all right?
Fit as can be, just... lost in thought. I can't shake... no, not now. I need to think on this some more.
As you wish, Kanchou. You can have all the time in the world to formulate a response.
That's not what I-
Can't hear you! Fetching cigarettes!
About last time...
I was wondering when we'd bring this back up. The suspense has been killing me.
It hasn't been that long, has it?
Our definitions of long are quite different. I'm technically quite young... though with the memory of centuries.
I don't doubt it. Back to what I was saying: I've been pondering how the Funayūrei fit into your idea of distance versus my idea of visibility regarding safety.
Have you cracked the nut, then?
I haven't shelled the nut, but at least I now know what I'm looking at.
So, you're saying you need to look more closely at...

Fields.MenuText: Don't be crude, Kaga.
Yes, yes, I get it.
I flatly refuse to engage in that, Kaga.

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes you're a real bore, you know that, Kanchou?
Do you? Do you get it? Get what it... ah, never mind. You're dull today.
So I've heard, right? No seriously, right? Ugh, you're so stiff sometimes!
Better that than being distracted.
At least you've got that going for you. Now, about those thoughts...
*ALARM*
Apparently the Funayūrei aren't much for conversation.
@BATTLE
I hear some of them are big talkers.
Well, other Belles and their kanchous need to step up their game. How does anyone hear them over the explosions?
No interruptions this time.
At least not until you get past the good parts, I hope.
I was simply wondering why the Funayūrei have been known to use mists. Which side would they fall on: distance or invisibility?
Clearly they're on the side of invisibility. The mists should make that obvious.
That was my original thought as well, but something kept bothering me about it. It finally hit me that perhaps they're not trying for invisibility so much as stealth.
Well, they're not always in the mists. Otherwise indirect fire would completely counter them.
So what I'm thinking is that they use the mists as a cover to help them close the distance between themselves and their opponents... hence, distance equals safety.
Distinction without a difference, I think.

Fields.MenuText: Distinctions can be the difference between victory and defeat.
Honestly, it's still a little subtle for even me.
Even the thought of a distinction makes me feel like a fool.

Fields.DialogueText: I think I can distinguish between a Funayūrei and an island. What more do we need?
Too subtle for you? I don't think you're feeling well, Kanchou. Subtlety isn't really my thing. Although if it were, I'd be ten times better at it than you.
Thinking it's too short a shave to go from one to the other? Join the club.
Perhaps. There's just something about it that won't leave me alone...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Several somethings, Kanchou, and they're every one of them spooky and evil. Light 'em up!
Kanchou, I think I have it!
Should I ask if it's catching?
Not the right time! I think I have an answer to your question about the mists!
Will it help us against the Funayūrei?
They... well, not in the short term, no. They're not a common tactic except near the maelstroms.
Then it doesn't really matter.
Doesn't matter? You couldn't think straight for how long and now you're saying it doesn't matter?

Fields.MenuText: That's right, it doesn't matter.
I just... it isn't as important right now.
I'm sorry, I just... I can't focus on that anymore.

Fields.DialogueText: Doesn't... How can you just drop this!?
Not important? What's with you?
I bet you could focus if I slapped you in the face! Is that what you need?
I said let it go, so just let it go, okay?
I won't, not since...
*ALARM*
You can't just start a debate and then duck out when you're losing. This isn't the end, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, about that issue...
I don't want to talk about it.
I just don't understand how you can be up in arms one day and uncaring the next.
Uncaring isn't the right word, Kaga.
Well what is, then?
Let's just say that I had my priorities reexamined.
By whom?
By someone who told me to stop focusing on the small things and get my mind back on the war at hand.
But who knew you were focusing on small things?
I... hmm... I thought we were the only ones, but now that you mention it...
So you didn't tell anyone else?

Fields.MenuText: That's what I said, isn't it?
No, not that I remember.
If I didn't tell anyone, maybe it was you!

Fields.DialogueText: I question you because it matters, Kanchou. Now focus!
Not that you remember? What do I keep you around for?
In the annals of absurdity, Kanchou, you just wrote a new bestseller.
All right, all right, I'm thinking. Just... where to start?
Let's say it had to be the two of us. Where did we talk about this? Was there anyone there who could have overheard?
Hmm... I can think of a few places, but...
*ALARM*
The bridge, of course!
@BATTLE
So someone on the bridge radioed headquarters?
They felt our discussions were becoming too personal.
Too personal? Isn't it good to know more about those with whom you serve?
Everyone sees their duty differently, Kaga. This crewman thought that our discussions distracted me from the war.
They didn't. If anything, they helped, didn't they?

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't have thought so, but yes. Yes, they did.
Of course they did!
Only like a dentist helps pull a rotten tooth.

Fields.DialogueText: So they helped. No need to be embarrassed.
Then why so confused about them?
Distinction without a difference, if I may resort to your greatest weakness.
It's not that, it's... I can't explain.
So what's the problem then? If it helped like you say it did...
Well, suppose they had a point?
@BATTLE
In what way?
*ALARM*
We were... distracted. Yes, that's it.
You're sure driving me to distraction.
Kanchou, about the snoops...
I'd rather we put this behind us, Kaga.
Yes, but don't you see? They fit perfectly in our talk about distance vs visibility.
Intriguing. How so?
Because no one confronted you personally. They felt that having some distance between you and them would keep them safe.
No, they kept themselves invisible by using other means.
Yes, distant means. They were like my bombers, striking from a distance. Pure and chaste from afar...

Fields.MenuText: Sounds romantic.
Cheating?
Reckless?

Fields.DialogueText: Where else but on the battlefield? ... That is, in theory.
I'd never cheat on you, Kanchou! Er, that is... it's not cheating if the enemy doesn't play by the rules.
It's not reckless if you acknowledge risk!
Kaga, I...
KANCHOU! Surely you aren't saying my bombers are...
No, no, of course not! I'm still just a touch bitter that a member of my own crew would go around me instead of speaking with me directly.
Don't take it too personally, Kanchou. Fear can sometimes be a wonderful motivating factor.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
... As can irritation.
Returning to our discussion on safety...
We're back to that, now? Are you comfortable with the crew?
I've moved past it. Regarding the two of us, I decided to take my orders from Command under advisement.
Under advisement? Kanchou, that sounds dangerously close to disloyalty. What happened to your respect for the chain of command?
They weren't truly orders. More like stringent suggestions to pull my head out of my stern and act accordingly.
Leave the naval metaphors to the ship, Kanchou. What's accordingly?

Fields.MenuText: Destroy the enemy whenever and wherever we encounter them.
Be prudent with the lives and equipment assigned us.
I'm still awaiting clarification on that.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, that goes without saying. Did we really need to be told?
Ha! As if we'd waste the Emperor's men or machines.
Then wait no further, Kanchou, lest I give it to you!
Elegant as always, Kaga.
Of course. The question now is, will you? Act accordingly, that is?
I shall act as I see fit, and right now, I think it is fit to continue our discussion on safety.
*ALARM*
So we clear the seas of these Funayūrei. What could be safer than victory?
@BATTLE
So you see, safety in numbers is actually another variation on being invisible. The gazelle remains invisible and therefore safe only as long as they remain with the herd.
Good point, Kanchou, but perhaps another view would change your mind.
This should be interesting. Please continue.
Whether or not the gazelle is visible is irrelevant. The lion cannot kill the animal it cannot catch, thus making distance the deciding factor.
We've gone over this how many times now and still gone nowhere? It seems we are at an impasse.
And if we are? Does it matter?
No, no it does not. I've found the discussions rather invigorating, actually.
As have I. Permission to speak frankly?

Fields.MenuText: Granted, of course.
As if I could stop you. Granted.
If you must, but make it quick.

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate your confidence, Kanchou.
Don't look so resigned. I'm only talking common sense.
I can be the very soul of brevity, Kanchou.
The point, Kaga?
Yes, well, perhaps we've reached a point where we can agree that each other's idea is sound and move forward from here?
An excellent suggestion. Whether through distance or visibility, we both agree that the safety of our pilots and equipment come first.
Then may I suggest we move forward by working on the solution at hand? The bombers need lightening. Let's focus on that.
Agreed. Let's get to work.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, I've spoken with the engineers and they have some interesting ideas.
If they're the same ones they gave me a while back, I've already heard them.
No, they assure me these are different. Instead of focusing on the engine, they focused on the internal struts and wing makeup.
Without weakening the fuel tanks?
Absolutely without weakening them.
Then where are they taking the wing weight from?
Do you really want to know?

Fields.MenuText: Of course I do! My ship, my men!
No, I have too many other things to do right now.
Only if you can answer quickly.

Fields.DialogueText: Mine too, Kanchou. Don't forget that. Anyway...
Good, then you'll sign off on my approach. What we're doing is...
Nobody does speed quite like...
*ALARM*
Or not.
@BATTLE
Shikata ga nai. You'll find out!
Wait, what do you mean? Come back here!
... and that's how they're doing it.
Excellent. When can they have it done?
They've been working on it during their spare time since we spoke. It shouldn't be long now.
Well done. I'll start reviewing the crew postings to see who would make the best test pilot.
Already picked one, Kanchou.
Excuse me?
I figured since I spend more time with the pilots and in the hangar, the decision should fall to me. Obviously.
You overstep your bounds, Kaga. The entirety of the ship is my responsibility and as such, my decision.
Excuse me for skipping the rubber stamp.

Fields.MenuText: Did you at least pick someone who wanted the job?
I'm not here just to sign off on your experiments, you know.
All right, maybe you do have a point. I'd still like to know about these things.

Fields.DialogueText: Nope. He volunteered.
Only most of them.
The day of or the day before, Kanchou. Your choice.
Let's move on. I will look at the postings and...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
... Table this conversation.
Kaga, a moment please.
Kanchou, I... ah, pilot, good to see you.
And you, Lady Kaga.
Ah, respect. See what I'm used to, Kanchou?
I wanted to ensure I had a chance to meet him face to face before his test flight.
We've all met, Kanchou.
Yes, but before we send him into danger, we owe him the courtesy of looking him in the eye and assuring him we've done all we can do to keep him safe.
I wouldn't expect anything different.
And have we, Kaga? Have we done everything we can to keep him safe?
I'd bet my life on it, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: Considering you're not easily killed, that's not very reassuring.
Yours and his.
Interesting choice of words, but acceptable.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll die of shame if this doesn't work. Does that count?
I'd tell you not to scare him, but he's already fearless. Don't you worry.
Better that I bet your life on it?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Still want to go through with it?
With the Kami at my back, anything is possible!
Attaboy! Now get out there and unleash hell!
Nervous, Kaga?
No.
No? That's all I get, no? After all we've done to make this happen, no?
Yes.
Yes? Seriously, what's... ah, I get it. You're nervous.
AM NOT.
I can see it in your eyes. You're nervous. That's what all the monosyllabic answers are for.
The mono what?

Fields.MenuText: Ha! I knew I could get you!
Just making sure you were listening.
You don't know "monosyllabic?"

Fields.DialogueText: So you're just having some fun with me? This isn't a game, you know.
I'm hearing. Isn't that enough?
I don't get your humor. But that in itself is kind of funny.
Just let it go, Kaga. It isn't worth fighting over humor.
Radio contact, Captain. It's the X1.
Experimental flight 1.
Flight reports better than expected distance and time, Captain.
HOORAY!
Flight also reports incoming Funayūrei.
Good thing we were out there looking. Prepare for combat.
@BATTLE
What's our next move, Kanchou?
Now we begin retrofitting our planes to the new specifications.
Just like that? But what about orders from Command?
I've already received their orders. They told me to act appropriately, so I am.
Ahh... giving them a taste of their own medicine?

Fields.MenuText: Absolutely not! Well, a little.
Absolutely not. Why would I do that?
Absolutely!

Fields.DialogueText: Tasty, I'm sure.
Because it's what I would do, and you have bottomless respect for my reasoning.
That'll show them!
Regardless, we're moving forward.
Very well, then. Far be it from me to question the kanchou, especially when right.
Good, especially since I'm always right. Why are you looking around like that?
Checking to see if the gods of the sea will strike you down for hubris.
You don't know "monosyllabic," but you know hubris?
You and I read different books.
Same author.
Not even in the same genre.
Now who's making things personal?
You're making it difficult not to.
*ALARM*
Speaking of things difficult...
Ha! They'll have to get up pretty early in the morning to make me break a sweat...
So, Kanchou...
So, Kami?
I'd prefer Lady Kaga, you know.
You're a kami, aren't you? A god. Well, small g.
What if I'm a big one?
In the grand scheme of things, does it matter?
It could make all the difference in the world!
What's gotten into you all of a sudden?
I'm sorry, I guess I'm just a little on edge. The last few battles have me wanting to push the engineers to retrofit faster.
They're working as quickly as they can.
I know, I know, but they need to work faster. Lives are at stake!

Fields.MenuText: You could always help, you know.
Give them their space. They're only human.
You're right; human lives. Back off!

Fields.DialogueText: What do you think I've been doing!? I can't be down there all the time.
That's good advice, Kanchou, but I think I'll keep my own counsel.
My ship, my humans, so don't go throwing that kind of advisory at me!
Advis... ? Don't go throwing my own words back...
I'm about to start throwing bombers! We've got Funayūrei...
@BATTLE
Kanchou, how do you feel about spreading the word of our progress to the others?
I'm not sure they would accept our word, but...
Why not?
In case you haven't noticed, Kaga, your mere presence makes us something of an anomaly among the fleet.
But I'm not the only one of my kind in the ocean.
True, but still, you are something different, and many people continue to fear that which is different. You have to admit that many have good historical reason for this.
Well, that I can't argue with...
That's a first.
... but I have to wonder why they would spurn something that could help us win the war.

Fields.MenuText: Let them worry about their pilots while we worry about ours.
Not everyone has the benefit of knowing you as I do, Kaga.
Because they think their way is better. Who knows? Maybe it is.

Fields.DialogueText: They can weed their gardens before planting in ours.
If only the blind could have the same knowledge of the sun.
Is the way of the ant any better than the grasshopper in spring?
What?
That's a compliment.
I'd hope so. A proverb?
@BATTLE
You think I'd sail at your side with an insult?
You might say that. I made it up.
Then how is that a proverb?
They've all got to come from somewhere. I thought we should go into battle with something entirely our own.
As long as it's a compliment.
If you felt I deserved one.
You're learning! And for what it's worth, you haven't deserved one in at least...
Don't finish that.
Hai. To war!
If it's done, it's done. It can't be undone.
Exactly why we should send word to the entire fleet.
But only through proper channels.
Curse your fixation on procedure. Those will take too long.
They take exactly as long as they take. We can't cut the Imperial Navy out of all the decisions.
But we've proven it's safe!
We've proven it's safe for us.
Kanchou, we...

Fields.MenuText: Enough, Kaga! My decision is final.
Kaga, please? For me.
At ease, Kaga. You'll just have to teach them.

Fields.DialogueText: Fine then. Shall I begin drawing up the instructions?
Oh, don't pull that. ... Fine. I'll pull together a manual.
With pleasure. I'll start assembling a curriculum, then?
Don't bother. I've had the engineers working on it from the second the test flight was completed.
Then why all the misdirection?
No misdirection, Kaga, just simple chain of command. We...
Incoming Funayūrei!
@BATTLE
Here comes some Funayūrei chain of command...
So you're saying you forwarded on the instructions through the chain of command to keep yourself safe?
Us, but yes. By sending them along as I did, I kept my distance from the decision. I thought you'd approve. After all, in this case, distance does equal safety.
Really? And here I was thinking that by sending them in via courier, you were keeping yourself invisible and thus safe.
It's good to see we can argue each other's point well enough to convince ourselves.
If I understood what you were saying, I'd have to agree.
I tell you, Kaga, I look forward to these little talks of ours. So many things on this ship are clockwork, but this... this is pure chaos.
Is that a good thing?

Fields.MenuText: Sadly, no. Seeing the chaos makes me appreciate the order.
Sadly, yes. Being in the midst of this makes my heart pump, but without the incoming fire usually attached.
Without a doubt, Kaga, without a doubt.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, if you know how to navigate the chaos, it's only chaotic for other people.
What an eloquent way to state your feelings.
I'm glad you feel that way, Kanchou. My heart is equally aligned.
I say what I mean, and I mean what I say.
Now, there's something else I want to say, something...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Well, now I know we're going to win.
How's that?
Because nothing will stand between me and what I want to say to you.
Kanchou, permission to speak frankly.
Haven't we been through this before? Fine, fine, speak frankly.
Kanchou, I feel I can no longer work with you without speaking my mind on a certain issue.
You have my full attention, Kaga. Please speak freely.
Thank you. In all the time we've been together, long or short as it has seemed, I've found working with you on the bombers to be the most invigorating thing I've ever experienced.
Thank you.
I'm not finished. Our discussions on philosophy, history, how you opened up to me regarding the issues of the bridge crew... it all made me realize something I've been missing.
And what was that?
Companionship, only something deeper. I've come to realize I have feelings for you that are perhaps more than I should. I... I can't help but wonder if maybe you feel them too?
Try as I might, I can't deny them. Yes, there's clearly something between us that needs exploring.
I feel it too, Kanchou. It'd be a waste to let these go unexplored.
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: We're needed on the bridge. Hmm... after you, Lady Kaga.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Kanchou. We'll continue this conversation after we've finished doing what we do best.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: What a happy coincidence.

Fields.DialogueText: Coincidence, hell. We think alike... and feel alike.

Fields.MenuText: How best to do the exploring?

Fields.DialogueText: The same way we do everything. Together.
